awd_titl_txt: An Accelerated Associate to Master’s Degree Pathway in Data Analytics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will contribute to the national need for well-educated data analysts and scientists, mathematicians, engineers, and technicians by supporting the retention and graduation of high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need at Bunker Hill Community College and Northeastern University. Over its one-year duration, this project will support the development of a Track 3 S-STEM proposal, that will outline a plan to provide scholarships to over 100 unique full time and part time students who are pursuing associate, bachelor’s, and master’s degrees in data science. This project intends to develop a proposal for an S-STEM project that would support data analyst/science students through the entire pathway from associates to bachelor’s to master's degrees in the data science field. Responding to national concerns about the high cost of postsecondary education and the demand for data science professionals, the program intends to offer a low-cost, accelerated alternative to earn degrees and enter careers in data science. The Track 3 S-STEM program developed in this project intends to provide scholarships, but additionally, the program will embed students in a supportive, accelerated pathway that prepares them for academic success and for data science careers in the greater Boston metro area. With strong industry support, the engagement of local community partners, and workforce development partners, local high schools and local industry partners, and together with existing infrastructure and articulation agreements between Northeastern University and Bunker Hill Community College, this program aims to encourage, enhance, and accelerate student engagement in academic preparation, career development, and entry into the STEM workforce.

The overall goal of this project is to increase STEM degree completion of low-income, high-achieving undergraduates with demonstrated financial need by preparing a proposal for a program that provides appropriately tailored pathways to STEM credentials tied to entry-level data analyst/science jobs that are in demand in the Boston area. The program to be developed will facilitate participation in undergraduate research and paid internships, industry and peer mentorship, specialized advising, and other tailored academic, career, and social supports that are recognized by researchers as high impact practices in broadening participation and increasing retention. Over the course of the project, industry partnerships will be established to ensure that the program is aligned with industry demands and the growing data analyst/science field. Results of this project will support the development of a larger S-STEM grant that will contribute to the STEM workforce and understanding of strategies to support the success of lower income students. This project is funded by NSF’s Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics program, which seeks to increase the number of low-income academically talented students with demonstrated financial need who earn degrees in STEM fields. It also aims to improve the education of future STEM workers, and to generate knowledge about academic success, retention, transfer, graduation, and academic/career pathways of low-income students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this planning grant was to design, write, and submit a proposal for an S-STEM Track 3 (Inter-institutional Consortia) project. Expanding on an existing S-STEM grant funding an Associate to Masters (A2M) pipeline between local community colleges and Northeastern University for biotechnology students, this planning grant supported work to design an A2M program for data analytics programs and students.

 

Over the 12 months of this project, Northeastern University solidified partnerships by meeting with potential partners, assessing their potential role in the data pathway being proposed.  Partners formed a leadership team to plan and implement our proposal development activities.   Our leadership team consisting of representatives of Northeastern University, Bunker Hill Community College and EDC met bi-weekly throughout the grant period to develop and operationalize a work plan that would result in an S-STEM proposal. The leadership team, led by Northeastern University, spent the first two months engaged in design sessions outlining the critical elements of our Data Science S-STEM program linking Bunker Hill’s Data Analytics program with Northeastern’s Bachelors in Analytics, which then fed into Master of Professional Studies in Informatics, Geospatial Intelligence, or Applied Machine Intelligence programs. During that period the team reviewed and discussed the characteristics and strengths of Northeastern’s S-STEM program in Biotechnology with Middlesex Community College, and what refinements could be made to adapt that program to produce a pipeline to Data Science careers.

 

As a result of our planning efforts, partners developed a proposal requesting a total of 279 S-STEM scholarships across five years, totaling roughly $3m in scholarship money handed out across the three levels of degree described in our pathway. Starting with 16 AS students, 20 BS students, and 5 MPS students in the first year, we planned for 15% year over year growth in the programs. Student selection criteria were formalized, and an investigation into the demographics of our current populations of learners revealed opportunities for improvement for retention and graduation rates. Infrastructure to support learners at both institutions was investigated, and new wraparound services were defined that could be implemented to support A2M students who are primarily under-represented minorities and first generation college students.

 

Additionally, our partners at EDC and an external evaluator created a research plan and logic model to study and evaluate the pathway across research questions investigating student outcomes and programmatic outcomes. Data collection and measures were defined, and a rigorous evaluation plan was developed.

 

Informal professional development occurred as a result of the collaboration between Northeastern, Bunker Hill Community College, and EDC. All parties expanded their current knowledge of associates-to-masters pathways and how to study them effectively. The groundwork for increased inter-institution collaboration was established, and a positive relationship was forged with research partners and evaluators. We also received letters of support from industry partners as part of the grant application process that could be used to train and grow our BS and MPS students via our experiential network courses and co-op opportunities.

 

Partnerships formed during this project have strengthened the institutional relationships among partners and the data pathway from Bunker Hill Community College to Northeastern University. 

Lessons learned through this project are contributing to better designed career pathways in other emerging fields being considered by partners. Staff in all partner institutions are more knowledgeable about the essential elements needed to develop strong career pathways and the supports students need to persist along career paths that span institutions.  This knowledge empowers them to design strong programs and establish support services that can increase recruitment and retention in their programs. As institutional capacity increases with knowledge on how to develop strong career pathways for emerging fields and the support systems needed to recruit and retain students, more students will be able to enter the workforce for emerging occupations filling important workforce development goals in a nation focused on leadership in discovery and innovation.

 

Meeting the increasing demand for data analysts ensures the United States remains competitive with peer nations in science and technology. From a business perspective, it is critical to leverage data and technology, embed analysts in the comprehension of what the business, organizational, and/or educational questions are, and anchor that understanding in the human ability and innovation to recognize opportunities and barriers and provide actionable solutions. Organizations need to have access to talented employees who combine these technical and human skills, and state-of-the-art analytics education serves that need.


 

 


Last Modified: 08/09/2023
Modified by: Uwe Hohgrawe
